meta.content: Effect of Ultraviolet Irradiation on the Material Properties and Acoustic Emission of a Fiber-reinforced Composite
meta.name: twitter:title

meta.content: Fibers and Polymers - We report the effect of exposure to up to 300 h of ultraviolet (UV) irradiation on the material properties and acoustic emission (AE) of glass fiber-reinforced composite...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: Effect of Ultraviolet Irradiation on the Material Properties and Acoustic Emission of a Fiber-reinforced Composite
meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: Fibers and Polymers 2021 22:7
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2021 The Korean Fiber Society
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: We report the effect of exposure to up to 300 h of ultraviolet (UV) irradiation on the material properties and acoustic emission (AE) of glass fiber-reinforced composite specimens. The tensile strength decreased by up to 30 % due to photodegradation, which caused extensive matrix cracking and interfacial debonding. Although a global parameter of structural health (the b-value) tended to increase with increasing exposure to UV light, it decreased after 300 h of exposure. The AE signals were more highly attenuated in the irradiated specimens, and the contribution of low-amplitude AE signals to attenuation was greater. To demonstrate the effect of attenuation, a numerical study was carried out based on frequency-dependent attenuation rates calculated from the experimental results. Simulations clarified the influence of attenuation rate on the b-value of the degraded composite.

meta.content: Effect of Ultraviolet Irradiation on the Material Properties and Acoustic Emission of a Fiber-reinforced Composite - Fibers and Polymers

We report the effect of exposure to up to 300 h of ultraviolet (UV) irradiation on the material properties and acoustic emission (AE) of glass fiber-reinforced composite specimens. The tensile strength decreased by up to 30 % due to photodegradation, which caused extensive matrix cracking and interfacial debonding. Although a global parameter of structural health (the b-value) tended to increase with increasing exposure to UV light, it decreased after 300 h of exposure. The AE signals were more highly attenuated in the irradiated specimens, and the contribution of low-amplitude AE signals to attenuation was greater. To demonstrate the effect of attenuation, a numerical study was carried out based on frequency-dependent attenuation rates calculated from the experimental results. Simulations clarified the influence of attenuation rate on the b-value of the degraded composite.

head.title: Effect of Ultraviolet Irradiation on the Material Properties and Acoustic Emission of a Fiber-reinforced Composite | SpringerLink

Although a global parameter of structural health (the b-value) tended to increase with increasing exposure to UV light, it decreased after 300 h of exposure. The AE signals were more highly attenuated in the irradiated specimens, and the contribution of low-amplitude AE signals to attenuation was greater. To demonstrate the effect of attenuation, a numerical study was carried out based on frequency-dependent attenuation rates calculated from the experimental results. Simulations clarified the influence of attenuation rate on the b-value of the degraded composite.","datePublished":"2021-04-26","dateModified":"2021-04-26","pageStart":"1940","pageEnd":"1949","sameAs":"https://doi.org/10.1007/s12221-021-0423-1","keywords":"Polymer Sciences","image":"","isPartOf":{"name":"Fibers and Polymers","issn":["1875-0052","1229-9197"],"volumeNumber":"22","@type":["Periodical","PublicationVolume"]},"publisher":{"name":"The Korean Fiber Society","logo":{"url":"https://www.springernature.com/app-sn/public/images/logo-springernature.png","@type":"ImageObject"},"@type":"Organization"},"author":[{"name":"Jung, Doyun","affiliation":[{"name":"Korea Institute of Science and Technology","address":{"name":"Composite Materials Applications Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Wanju, Korea","@type":"PostalAddress"},"@type":"Organization"},{"name":"Tokyo Institute of Technology","address":{"name":"Department of Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan","@type":"PostalAddress"},"@type":"Organization"}],"@type":"Person"},{"name":"Mizutani, Yoshihiro","affiliation":[{"name":"Tokyo Institute of Technology","address":{"name":"Department of Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan","@type":"PostalAddress"},"@type":"Organization"}],"@type":"Person"},{"name":"Todoroki, Akira","affiliation":[{"name":"Tokyo Institute of Technology","address":{"name":"Department of Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan","@type":"PostalAddress"},"@type":"Organization"}],"@type":"Person"},{"name":"Na, Wonjin","affiliation":[{"name":"Korea Institute of Science and Technology","address":{"name":"Composite Materials Applications Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Wanju, Korea","@type":"PostalAddress"},"@type":"Organization"}],"@type":"Person"}],"@type":"ScholarlyArticle"},"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"WebPage"}

div.div: Effect of Ultraviolet Irradiation on the Material Properties and Acoustic Emission of a Fiber-reinforced Composite

header.h1: Effect of Ultraviolet Irradiation on the Material Properties and Acoustic Emission of a Fiber-reinforced Composite
header.p:
Fibers and Polymers
volume
22
,
pages
1940–1949 (
2021
)
Cite this article

li.p:
100
Accesses

2
Citations

1
Altmetric

div.p:
We report the effect of exposure to up to 300 h of ultraviolet (UV) irradiation on the material properties and acoustic emission (AE) of glass fiber-reinforced composite specimens. The tensile strength decreased by up to 30 % due to photodegradation, which caused extensive matrix cracking and interfacial debonding. Although a global parameter of structural health (the
b
-value) tended to increase with increasing exposure to UV light, it decreased after 300 h of exposure. The AE signals were more highly attenuated in the irradiated specimens, and the contribution of low-amplitude AE signals to attenuation was greater. To demonstrate the effect of attenuation, a numerical study was carried out based on frequency-dependent attenuation rates calculated from the experimental results. Simulations clarified the influence of attenuation rate on the
b
-value of the degraded composite.

Download
to read the full article text
